children.text: Today is a real “back to school” day. It's literally so for my daughters, who went off to start year 3 and year 6 this morning. And it's figuratively so for me, as I've got my first full working day for a long time.

children.caption: My eldest enjoying the campfire.
children.alt: A young girl kneeling by a woodland campfire.

children.text: We're just back from a lovely week camping in the woods — with even less internet access
than our earlier trip

. So, yes, this is another catch-up thread. The summer really has failed to live up to the old “silly season” moniker — there's been plenty happening while many of us have been desperately trying to escape our screens…
(Summer holidays: a period of time when parents try to escape screens, and children try to get time on them.)
Hang on to your hats, folks. We'll be looking at some interesting moves in local news, SEO, Twitter and more.
Putting the “local” in local news

There's so many bad stories about local news in the UK that I rarely bother to link to them any more. At some point, I'll gather them together and write something longer, but at the heart of my thoughts is that there's still too much “doing journalism” and not enough “doing journalism that people
really
care about”. Here's Ian Carter making exactly that point:
We are getting the best response from the stories that involve detailed reporting on the issues that really matter to people, ideally offering solutions and conclusions.
Don't focus on abstract news values: focus on what people really need in their daily lives.

metadata.title: Being better
metadata.description: I was reading the memoirs of former Q editor Ted Kessler on holiday when I stumbled across a passage that had me nodding so vigorously that the woman on the adjacent sun lounger must have thought I…
metadata.author: iancarterblog

children.text: In the meantime, the picture looks grim for a lot of the regional press. Reach's journalists have been on strike, and the cost-of-living crisis has been making their salaries inadequate:
Press Gazette has spoken to nine Reach journalists and has heard stories of reporters taking up second jobs as lecturers, copywriters or selling items on Etsy to make ends meet.

metadata.title: Reach journalists report taking second jobs to pay bills amid staff strike
metadata.description: Reach journalists have reported being unable to afford childcare or use the heating, while many have taken second jobs to make ends meet, as strike starts.
metadata.author: Twitter

children.text: But let's not be entirely negative here.
Behind Local News
has been running a series profiling the Facebook-funded community news reporters and what's happened to them. This piece has a nice example of successful community-centric reporting:

metadata.title: Becoming a reporter gave me a sense of purpose in my new community
metadata.description: For community reporter Eve McLachlan, it has been a real adjustment to living in the Western Isles and reporting on its remote communities.
metadata.author: Behind Local News

children.text: (Although, one does wonder what's going to happen to this scheme, now Meta is
less willing to fund journalism
A large Medium error
Once upon a time, I used to
write a lot about Medium here

. It occupied roughly the same mindspace in the journalism world that Substack does now. And that it faded away. Its founder, Ev Williams, recently stepped down in favour of a new CEO who was a prolific publisher on the platform. And he thinks that Williams' focus on journalism was an error:

“For me, fundamentally, the mistake was thinking that journalism was where Medium was going to shine,” he said. “We have the source material that feeds journalism. In a lot of ways that’s unique and special. And Medium exists to do something unique. It’s not supposed to reinvent the wheel.”
In other words, he's going to focus on making what's essentially old-school blogging pay. Good luck. All those newsletter platforms are playing in that space…

metadata.title: Medium’s new CEO on the company’s journalism mistakes, bundle economics, and life after Ev Williams
metadata.description: “For me, fundamentally, the mistake was thinking that journalism was where Medium was going to shine.”
metadata.author: Casey Newton

children.text: Do you want a SLAPP?
Good piece from
CJR

looking at the growing threat of legal action being used to stifle journalism, because the publishers in question can't afford to contest it. The more micro publishers we have, the more this is going to be a problem:

metadata.title: A Nefarious and Hidden Threat to Journalists Rises
metadata.description: At the end of last year, two hundred and ninety-three journalists were in jail around the world (a modern record), and dozens more had been killed. There are robust mechanisms for documenting and denouncing those cases. But no one knows precisely how many journalists were hit with crippling and f…
metadata.author: Joel Simon and Carlos Lauria

children.text: Better Meta
No, not the Facebook owner, but
Meta Descriptions

. Google has updated its guidelines with some clear examples of what a good and bad Meta Description looks like. There's nothing new here — but this might be a useful resource to show your developers or site managers if you're currently using one of the bad examples, as many publishers are.

metadata.title: How to Write Meta Descriptions | Google Search Central | Documentation | Google Developers
metadata.description: Learn how to write a quality meta description tag that may be displayed for your page in Google Search results by following these best practices.

children.text: Twitter goes tiling
Twitter is letting a few publishers play around with some more attractive link boxes and other visual formats. Worth keeping an eye on, if it proves successful.

children.text: Nieman Lab
has a little more info

children.calloutText: Talking of Twitter, it's moving aggressively into podcasts with upgrades to its Spaces feature. And that's rather ironic, given that the company started as a podcasting business called Odeo…

children.text: A handy SEO tool: an alternative site speed checker

Given how important site speed and user experience has become to Google search (especially the metric it calls “Core Web Vitals”), this is a handy little tool to use in conjunction with Google's own tools.

metadata.title: Treo: Page Speed Monitoring
metadata.description: Treo makes it easy to track your site’s web performance, test new features, and benchmark against competitors.

children.text: And finally… the lifecycle of social media
(or why brands ruin everything)
A lovely cartoon and post from Tom Fishburne, who's watched this cycle play out more than once.

metadata.title: Lifecycle of Social Media cartoon - Marketoonist | Tom Fishburne
metadata.description: It’s inevitable. As soon as a new social platform starts to attract an audience, brands will follow — sometimes with awkward attempts to “authentically” engage that audience. It can be a tricky dance for marketers when part of the appeal of a platform is the absence of brands. The latest social netw…
metadata.publisher: Marketoonist | Tom Fishburne - Marketoonist is the thought bubble of Tom Fishburne. Marketing cartoons, content marketing with a sense of humor, keynote speaking.

children.calloutText: Coming up this week: more catch-up links, a piece on what's happened to newsletter open rates and a piece on the campaign to shut down Kiwi Farms, and what you should know about it. (If I can bring myself to write about it. It's the sort of subject that brings attention from the sorts of people you really don't want attention from…)
